headline: CNN This Morning
subHeadline: Denver Airport to Conduct Airline Reviews Amid Cancellations. Warwick Reflects on Confronting Racism and Raising Awareness for AIDS Education. New Year's Resolution: How Americans View "Dry January". Rolling Stone Releases New "500 Greatest Albums of All Time" Book. Aired 8:30-9a ET

utterances.speaker: KAITLAN COLLINS, CNN THIS MORNING HOST
utterances.sentences: OK. Just so you do still expect to eventually have that job leading the FAA?

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: Well we'll see what happens. Tomorrow's not promised anybody, so we'll see what happens. And I can say this. Whatever job I have I'll do the best that I possibly can.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: OK. Phillip Washington, I know you are very busy this morning. You've got a lot of unclaimed baggage there. Thank you for taking time to talk about the real impacts that this chaos had on your airport. We appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WASHINGTON
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN THIS MORNING HOST
utterances.sentences: Oh man, she is one of the greatest singers of all time. Dionne Warwick's distinctive voice that some have said it's like finding water in a desert. It has thrilled her legions of fans, and over the decades the legendary vocal artist has brought us countless hits like "Alfie", "Do You Know the Way to San Jose", while also breaking through racial barriers and shining a spotlight on important social issues. The new CNN film, "Dionne Warwick(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: DIONNE WARWICK, SINGER
utterances.sentences: The shows were completely sold out every night. There was one side, which was white, where they were seated, and the other side was a ballroom-type setting where everybody was standing. Blacks were on the side, whites were on this side. The stage was straight ahead, and I remember Sam saying, "Dionne, do not turn your back on the white folk." And I said, "Well why not?" He said, "Do not turn your back on the white folk." I said, "OK". The first thing I did when I went out there, I walked straight to the band and turned my back and played to the ones that looked like me. Everybody could hear me. Everybody could see me.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Joining us now the legend herself, Dionne Warwick. So outspoken, Dionne. Thank you so much for joining us. I really appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: My pleasure, my darling. You know I love you.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: I love you as well. This is a beautiful film about your incredible life and career. Why'd you decide to let audiences in now to get such an intimate look at you and your life?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: You know, people have their own opinions and they suppose things. Now they know the real deal.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You were the first black person to win the pop vocal Grammy for "Do You Know the Way to San Jose" (sic). Did you ever imagine reaching these heights when you were signing in the gospel choir in jersey?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: No. As a matter of fact, I never really wanted to record.(LAUGHTER) I finally was talked into it because I was promised one particular song to be my first recording, and those songs make it easy on yourself. And Bacharach and David gave that song to Jerry Butler, and I was not very happy about that. (LAUGHTER) As a matter of fact, my first recording, "Don't Make Me Over", was because of something I said to them that they could not do, and that was make me over.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Oh really? You said don't try to make me --

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: -- into something that I'm not? Is that where that came from? WARWICK

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: This looks a the way that you had to deal with racism throughout your career, so tell us more about your approach when you faced that kind of injustice. Was that part of your "Do Not Make Me Over" approach?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: No. You know, I didn't know anything about that coming from eastern New Jersey AEA (ph), and that kind of confrontation I never even dreamed of. I mean, I lived on a street, Sterling Street in East Orange, but I really likened it to the United Nations where we really scored to create (ph) a religion on that street, and we all lived very comfortably together. We walked to school together. We had lunches together. People came to my home. I went to their homes. So being subjected to the madness because of the color of my skin travelling throughout the southern regions of our country, I kind of -- I understood the side (ph).(MUSIC)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: But this film also highlights, Ms. Warwick, your work on the AIDS crisis, and you helped so many people, and particularly your Grammy-winning hit, "That's What Friends Are For", which has raised millions and millions of dollars for the cause over these years. Why did you decide to speak out then because it wasn't so popular to do what you did?

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: That's why we love you. I've got to ask you.(LAUGHTER) And you know I also love you because, you know, I follow you on Twitter. I want to know how you feel about the changes under Elon Musk because you have people like Whoopi Goldberg saying I'm out until they fix this platform. Are you going to stay on the platform?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: No, I've not met Mr. Musk yet, and I intend to do that.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: You said you want to meet with him?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: Yes, I do. I want to see what he's really up to. I learn you never judge a book by its cover. You got to open it up and started reading it, and that's the way I feel about him as well, so I'm going to see what he wants and how he's really going to approach his new venture.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Yes. I got to tell people one of the biggest thrills of my life was an award that I got.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: And a surprise, they said someone is here to sing for you and introduce you, and it was you! I almost fell out of my chair. I could barely accept the award for crying. I know, you know, from knowing you that this is -- you know, there's still a lot more runway ahead for Dionne Warwick. So what is the next chapter? Do you know?

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: No. I haven't -- I don't know what God has in store for me. You know, I'm just following in the path he's leading me down.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Dionne Warwick, thank you. I love you so much. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WARWICK
utterances.sentences: That's the way I feel about you, too. You know that.

utterances.speaker: LEMON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That's a song, too.(LAUGHTER) Be sure to tune in the all-new CNN film, "Dionne Warwick:  Don't Make Me Over", premieres New Year's Day at 9 p.m. only here on CNN.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Cannot wait to watch that.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: She's amazing.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: She's so great.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh boy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We -- you don't even want to know what we were just talking about.(LAUGHTER) We are getting closer to New Year's Day, a time of year when we reflect on things that we want to change in the year ahead. Kaitlan has some ideas for me that -- (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's for myself to be fair.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: The subject of this morning's number with CNN's Senior Data Reporter, Harry Enten.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Are you crying from laughing? Harry, OK.

utterances.speaker: HARRY ENTEN, CNN SENIOR DATA REPORTER
utterances.sentences: I'll save both of you. How about that? OK. So this morning's number, what is it? This morning's number is -- it's 60 percent. That is Google searches for dry January in the week leading up to Christmas. It's up 60 percent from where we were in 2021. It's up 300 percent from where we were in 2017. Of course, the idea of dry January is that you don't take in alcohol during the month of January, and it's clear from these numbers that a lot more people are interested at least in the idea of dry January.Now, why would they be interested in the idea of dry January? Because there are a lot of benefits to it, right? A majority of those who follow the program reported saving money, sleeping better, weight loss, it's easier to focus, perhaps something we can work on here, fewer days drunk, even months later. So the fact of the matter is is that dry January is something that does help out those who are involved in it, and they see the effects of it even months later.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: But there -- it seems to have become a phenomenon and it seems like everyone's doing it. I have so many friends who do dry January. I personally do not because I think January's a tough month. It's like brutal weather. It's like, you know, people like to have a glass of wine. Are a lot of people doing it, or what does it look like what it comes to people who are still drinking?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes, yes. So, you know, Gallup has been tracking for years the percentage of Americans who drink alcohol, and we're not becoming dry because look at this trend line of the percentage of Americans or at least of adults who drink alcohol. It stayed very, very consistent. So 67 percent this year, and Gallup said that they did as compared to 66 percent 20 years ago, 65, 40, 63 nearly 50, and we're back to where we were in 1945 at 67 percent.So we're basically a country that is drinking the same percentage of alcohol that we have drank throughout the years, but I will point out one thing that really has changed is the perception of alcohol, how dangerous is alcohol? Which is more dangerous to use, alcohol or marijuana? Look at the -- look at this right year. 54 percent say alcohol compared to just 7 percent who say marijuana in 2022. If you compare that to where we were in 1974, it was a basic split. So what's happened is even if the same percentage of Americans are drinking alcohol as used to, the perception of how dangerous it is has clearly changed. A lot more people now think alcohol is dangerous, at least compared to marijuana.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That's really interest. I need to know what this last tab is, New Year's Eve Plan. Is that your New Year's Eve plan, Harry?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: It does sort of get to what my New Year's Eve plan is.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Are you going to Times Square with Kaitlan?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I am not going to Times Square. So are you going to be awake at midnight to ring in the New Year? 75 percent say it is likely. 25 percent say it is unlikely. I am definitely in the unlikely camp. If I do my New Year's Eve correctly, I am, in fact, going to be nice, cooked (ph) in bed by let's say 10, 10

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Resolution?

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Resolution --

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I want to be clear I'm not going to Times Square, but continue.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Good luck with this show.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Good luck with this show. That's why we're doing this at, you know, 8

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You got some pull with the producers here.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: You must know a guy.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes, you must know a guy.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: I got some pull. You know, it's because I bake these slides together (ph). They're very, very nice.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well we can't wait for more numbers in 2023.

utterances.speaker: ENTEN
utterances.sentences: Sounds great. I look forward to seeing it.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: All right. Rolling Stone Magazine has released a new book of their top 500 albums of all time. What topped to the list, and our personal favorites. We'll tell you that next.Sleeping where -- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Sleep more? Sleep more?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It tracks my sleep (ph).

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: We've been wanting that shot since we launched this show.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, they -- I mean, this is -- that is -- you see us on screen. That's what really happens behind the scenes. One big thing we're talking about --

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: And our -- and our producers earlier. You know, you can't forget them.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: And our producers you saw in the last one. They're clapping in the corner. OK, do you recognize this song?(MUSIC) Of course, as you know that is Marvin Gaye's "What's Going On". It is the top single from the number one album of this amazing book that Rolling Stone has put together. A new list of "The 500 Greatest Albums of All Time". Rolling Stone just published this new book along with a full list with a new poll with the results from some of the industry's most-celebrated artists, producers, and journalists. Joining us now to talk about this book and who made this list is Rolling Stone's Senior Writer, Brittany Spanos.

utterances.speaker: BRITTANY SPANOS, ROLLING STONE SENIOR WRITER
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much for having me. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: This book is just -- we're just -- we've all been like looking through it all morning.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's just incredible. How do you decide, though, because I know that like some people may not agree that Fleetwood Mac "Rumours" should be number seven, it should be number one.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Like how do you -- how do you decide?

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: So we had 300 voters weigh in on this list, and it's a combination of journalists in the industry, Rolling Stone staffers, but also a lot of musicians, a lot of industry experts. We had people like Beyonce and Stevie Nicks vote what their favorite albums, and they all submitted ballots. And we really lucked out because we had sent out the ballots and the information on it in late 2019, but then like everyone was home in 2020 and they had time. Like Beyonce would usually not have time to think about like her favorite albums, but she sat down and she submitted it. And so, I think there's a really great diverse number of voices who weighed in on what the greatest albums of all time were.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You guys did this in 2003, 2012 --

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- and now. So now looking through this, you've got Beyonce you mentioned, Taylor Swift, Stevie Nicks, Lin Manuel Miranda. It's just fascinating to see them all come together, and the control room, the team you just saw asked us to pick our favorites.(LAUGHTER) Can we pull Kaitlan's up here, guys?

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Why do I have to go first?

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Because you have to -- you're like better at this than I am.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Well mine -- "Rumours" is one of mine.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Also I lived Talking Heads, came in at number 39. Beyonce's "Lemonade" was 32. Of course, that's an incredible album.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes. COLLINS

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: I have mine. I'm an old school. Elton John, Otis Redding, and I grew up in a house listening to records of Bonnie Raitt.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Great choices, yes.(LAUGHTER) Love those choices.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: But is shows how diverse this list is.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, it's really incredible to see the way taste changed. I mean, everyone's sort of -- the controversy with both lists is the idea like do we need a list like this? And I think it's a really great compendium to look at the way that taste and kind of artist influence and impact changes over the years and also for really young music fans who kind of use this as a resources to learn about music history. And it's really fun to see like what was included, what bumped up, what bumped down, seeing newer albums, seeing more Latin albums, seeing younger artists, seeing more rap, seeing like everything kind of shift and become like a bigger melting pot of what music is today.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Something that surprised you as you were looking at the votes coming in?

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: You know, I'm a -- I'm a pop girl and I love pop music, and pop music is typically not super respected as classic and iconic. And so, it was really fun to see like Britney Spears' "Blackout" on this list. It's like one of my favorite albums. It ranked very highly on my personal ballot, and you know, I think seeing an album by an artist who was disrespected as not authentic being seen as one of the greatest albums of all time, to see an artist make that, it just felt really special to kind of see people put respect on pop music and on especially like female artists, young women who make music in this list.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: That is really special, and the selection process as people like Beyonce are casting their ballots, how does that work when you go through them and then you guys basically look at the numbers to see what that looks like as the rankings go?

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So everyone was asked to make their ballot in order. I believe it was 25 albums that everyone had to submit, and there was like a point system that we have. I wasn't the one who tabulated this, so I have no idea how it worked. I'm terrible with numbers, but there's a point system. Like if you had this number one, I think, you know, it's a certain number, like hundreds of points or something that helped actually kind of streamline it instead of just being like well this person put it at number one, so like let's put it in the top 10. Like very mathematical sort of way of doing this.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: It's cool. There's like a real science behind it.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Also a gorgeous book, so I can't wait to --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: I know. I mean, we have seriously been flipping through it all morning because it's just -- and it also reminds me of things. I'm like, oh, I need to go listen to that. (inaudible)

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: And I was home for Christmas and I found like the one that I had from the 2003 list.

utterances.speaker: COLLINS
utterances.sentences: Oh really?

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: I just think it's just like so nice to --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: You look like you must have been like 10 --

utterances.speaker: SPANOS
utterances.sentences: I was.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: HARLOW
utterances.sentences: -- in 2003. I was. Own it girl.
